In the event of more serious emergencies, the same personnel are trained and prepared to assist the efforts of other emergency response personnel in a variety of support roles.   All members of the Fire and Rescue Team have attended fire response training, multi-media first aid, C.P.R., and 24 hour HAZWOPER Technician level training.

Overall emergency response programs are coordinated with the Mobile Emergency Management Agency. This coordination includes briefings and information sharing to address specific concerns in the event of an incident at the plant and drills to practice skills. The LeMoyne Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with the Mobile Emergency Management Agency. This agency has the capability to communicate to all state, federal and county agencies and may draw on whatever resources or equipment are needed to effectively manage emergency operations (i.e., fire-fighting equipment, manpower, ambulances, hospitals, law enforcement, and HAZMAT operations). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating a quick response to an incident. The LeMoyne Site conducts drills annually to assess personnel readiness, proficiency, and the effectiveness of emergency response plans.

7.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the recently identified improvements include the addition of several Safety Instrumented System (SIS) interlocks, a flame arrestor, and new personal protective equipment (PPE). Some of the identified improvements have been fully implemented while others are in the process of being implemented.

Compliance Audits:
To assure that the goals of the accident prevention programs are met, program performance is periodically evaluated in the form of compliance audits. An audit team reviews the records and documents to determine the degree of program compliance. Compliance audits will be conducted at least every 3 years. Audit team findings are documented and presented to plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to audit findings are tracked until they are complete.  The two most recent audit reports are retained.

5.0 Five-Year Accident History
Within the last five years, there was one accidental release of chlorine that resulted in an onsite injury.  The release occurred on February 9, 2022, and resulted in an employee being exposed to chlorine above the permissible exposure limit.

6.0 Emergency Response Program
The LeMoyne facility maintains a written emergency action plan (EAP) designed to protect workers and public safety as well as the environment during an emergency. The plan consists of procedures for responding to a serious fire or explosion, release of toxic or hazardous chemicals, and other potential emergencies. These procedures address notification and emergency signals, specific containment actions, and proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel following an evacuation, e Work Practices: notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, as well as post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, the plant has procedures to address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment. All visitors and contractors receive some level of orientation to instruct them in emergency signals and actions to be taken during an

Moyne Site employs widely accepted safety work practices and incorporates Life Saving Rules into these Life Critical Procedures. These safe work practices used include (1) lockout procedures for control of hazardous energy, (2) entry/exit control procedures for maintenance, laboratory, contractor, and support personnel, (3) line breaking/opening process equipment procedures, (4) a hot work permit program to control possible ignition sources, and (5) a permit-required confined space entry procedure. These procedures are used by all personnel involved in both user and non-user maintenance activities.

Management of Change (MOC):
The site's management of change program is intended to review and evaluate changes to process chemistry, operating conditions or limits, equipment, and procedures before changes are made so as to prevent unexpected adverse impacts. The management of change program uses a quantitative risk assessment to determine the significance of the change. This risk level assessment determines the levels of authorization required to approve the action. Design review checklists are used to evaluate different types of changes to prevent new hazards being created or equipment changes that are not suited to the service as it exists in the process. Another feature of the management of change program is that it verifies and documents that procedures, records, and equipment information are updated and that personnel affected by the change are informed of and trained in the change.

Incident Investigation:
All incidents that result in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a release of a hazardous material, a fire or explosion in a covered process area, major property damage, adverse environmental impact, or serious personal injury must be reported and promptly investigated. By investigating accidents and near-misses, important lessons are learned. Corrective actions can then be implemented to prevent similar events in the future. Incident investigations are docum

onstruction of new process facilities. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment in service. This review provides additional verification that construction is in accordance with design specifications and that systems are operationally ready. Applicable checklists are used to verify various aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of equipment fabrication and installation and serves to assure that other accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity:
The LeMoyne site assures the mechanical integrity of critical operations equipment such as pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, and safety systems through its mechanical integrity program. The basic aspects of the mechanical integrity (MI) program include: (1) training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. Maintenance personnel receive training in (1) overviews of the process and its hazards, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) safe work practices to help ensure that they perform their jobs in a safe manner. Equipment deficiencies, once identified, are corrected prior to further operation of the equipment, or a management team will determine and prescribe how the equipment may continue safely in operation. As part of the mechanical integrity program, quality assurance measures are incorporated into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper material and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Following classroom orientation, the new employee begins coworker training with an experienced operator and a review of operating procedures applicable to his job. At the conclusion of this co-worker training period, the new employee is evaluated to ensure he possesses the skills and knowledge necessary to safely do his job. To supplement and reinforce job knowledge and skills, all employees undergo refresher training at regular intervals. Refresher training frequency ranges from each year to once every three years. Training is documented and understanding is verified using oral and written tests, performance observation and other means that objectively demonstrate the trainees level of understanding.

Contractor Safety Program:
The LeMoyne site employs contractors to perform special construction projects or supplement the maintenance workforce when needed. All contractors receive orientation training depending on the scope, nature, and location of their work. Contractors selection considers the existence and effectiveness of their safety programs and performance. Contractors undergo orientations where they are made aware of basic plant rules and safety policies, workplace hazards in the area they will work, safe work practices applicable to the jobs, and basic emergency response procedures. During this initial orientation, contract employees are instructed to report any hazards their work may create or that they discover during the course of their work. Contractors are periodically evaluated to ensure they are fulfilling their 
safety obligations.

Pre-Start-up Safety Reviews:
The LeMoyne site personnel perform pre-startup safety reviews (PSSRs) for facility modifications beyond replacements of equipment in kind on covered processes. This includes significant changes in process equipment or procedures or upon completing the c

ing assigned by the team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios with the highest risk receive more immediate attention. All approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained by the LeMoyne Site. The LeMoyne Site periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis studies using experience gained to improve process safety. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years for covered processes and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. Findings and recommendations from these updates are documented and retained. Recommendations made by the team updating or revalidating the PHA are again reviewed and resolved by management review with final resolution being documented and retained.

Operating Procedures:
The LeMoyne site maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) initial startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) startup following maintenance activities or following an emergency shutdown. Operating procedures are used as a reference by experienced operators and as a resource in training new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. Operating procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change (MOC) process. When creating or reviewing operating procedures, a team of personnel review and comment on the drafts accuracy and completeness. Procedures are available to operators and other personnel in work areas where process operations are performed.

Training:
Training is an essential part of the skills development program used for qualifying employees who will be involved in operating a process. New employees receive initial training in plan

using reliable process controls and monitoring instruments, emergency relief systems and two-stage scrubber system, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., emergency shutdown systems). Technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment are maintained digitally within the LeMoyne site's intranet. Hard copy backup of key critical information is maintained by Operations, HSES, and Engineering. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and Off-Site Consequence Analysis:
The LeMoyne site has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards and risks associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each new and altered process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure adequate controls are in place to manage the hazards. Methodologies used to perform these evaluations include hazard and operability study (HAZOP) and layer of protection analysis (LOPA). These analyses are conducted using cross-functional teams with operations and engineering expertise. Team members identify and evaluate hazard scenarios, ranking each scenario's risk level with respect to event likelihood and severity. The team also evaluates prevention and mitigation measures and makes appropriate recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures if they are judged necessary. The site management team reviews the PHA team's findings and recommendations. The management team establishes priorities for implementation of PHA recommendations based on a relative risk rank

In addition, the following specific prevention programs are in place:

Employee Participation:
The employees and management work together to manage process safety and accident prevention efforts. Employees participate in safety action committee meetings and the decision-making dialog in those meetings. Employees also hold and participate in their own subcommittee meetings and make recommendations to this steering group. Employees participate in process hazard reviews and in the development of operating procedures. They assist in updating and verifying technical documents and chemical information. Employees have access to all information created as part of this facility's accident prevention program. Employees are involved in developing and carrying out training, incident investigations, management of change, process hazard analyses and pre-startup safety reviews.

Process Safety Information:
Technical information on process equipment, technology, and chemicals is maintained and used to ensure safe operation of the covered processes. These documents address chemical properties and their associated hazards, limits for critical process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design and configuration details. Specific departments are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and other known hazards associated with inadvertently mixing of chemicals. For specific covered process areas, there are documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperatures, pressures). Operators ensure that the process is maintained within these limits

3.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards of the LeMoyne Nouryon facility.  These high standards include:
	Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
	Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases 
are minimized.
	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
	Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.

4.0 Prevention Program
The LeMoyne facility is operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and emphasis on safety have all helped minimize serious chemical release accidents over the years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:

	Fixed Deluge and Fire Monitoring Systems

1.0 Introduction and Policies
The LeMoyne Nouryon facility is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  Nouryon s management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of its Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility, and planned changes to improve safety at the plant.

2.0 Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The LeMoyne Nouryon Chemistry LLC Facility, located in Axis, Alabama, is operated by Nouryon to manufacture a variety of basic and specialty chemicals.

The facility is situated on a 650-acre plot located approximately 20 miles north of  Mobile, Alabama. The facility is located in an industrial area where other chemical manufacturing facilities are situated both to the north and south of the facility.  The Mobile River is located on the eastern edge of the Nouryon facility. 

Chlorine is one of the raw materials used to manufacture sulfur chlorides.  Sulfur chlorides are used to manufacture rubber, insecticides, chemicals, erasers, dyes, rubber substitutes, lubricant additives, and pharmaceuticals.  Carbon disulfide, commonly referred to as CS2, is used in the manufacture of rayon which is commonly used to make suits, blouses, and other items of clothing.  CS2 is also used to make sponges, gauze, rubber, solvents, disposable washcloths, dialysis filters, surgical face masks, coffee filters, insecticides/pesticides, oil and air filters, and cellophane.
